The original stronghold had a map/campaign line which was very hard but was always attainable. You may have to try different methods but was attainable. This version has the same but a shortened version of it and can be done over a day or two. Then there are the other campaigns where the first few in it are very hard and take a lot of work which is ok then they slowly get to the point where they are actually unattainable. You do not have enough resources and in some cases cannot even create certain buildings/tech that could help. I have tried certain campaigns over and over and over again using different tactics but due to lack of resources and a large enemy force coming at you at regular intervals  in the end you just give up. One campaign i started with 4 archers 6 knights and 4 maceman against 20 spearman, 8 archers, 6 knights and 10 pikeman in a fort. Spent about an hour letting my 4 archers pick off the enemy enough to let me get the win. To me this is just a waste of time. Then next scenario had a huge army that wipes you almost out then comes at you again and again every 10 mins and you have no resources to talk about to start. Spent hours trying this one but when they send 40+ knights/pikeman plus 20+ spearman and siege equipment every 10 mins does not make sense. If there was no siege equipment and a little more time between at least you would have a remote chance.
I spent many long hours in the old versions playing and actually redid them from time to time. This just seems to be leaving you with nothing to start and constant carp thrown at you that will always win out.

Horrible game.  The premise is city builder, yet the game completely dictates where you can build.  Using the "sandbox, you pick an area but when it's time to build something, the program will place a sapling in an area you spend an hour clearing.  Right when you are finally knocking down the last tree, a sapling will sprout immediately blocking you from building, as you chop it down, another will sprout.  It's time to build a house, you have all your houses in one area, they will place a child in the area you want to build.  Then the child won't move until another NPC is blocking the area.  It will freeze in place, making you think it's frozen, but the second something else blocks your build, it will come to life and move.  Like a changing of the guard  You want to build a drawbridge to your gatehouse, it won't let you, stating one box has red to block, so you tear down your gatehouse, losing the brick, move it to a spot where it won't touch the area, go to place the drawbridge and STILL won't let you build.  No red in the area, just still won't let you build.  For a city building, sandbox game, the program dictates what you can actually do.  Crap game.

Speaking strictly about game content added and not art assets or functionality, this is extremely disappointing. Most of the content added is no-build missions, which is not what Stronghold was particularly good at for a myriad of reasons. On top of that, the additional content is also at best sophomoric in map design, surpassed even by a cursory glance at the community made content for this game which has spanned over 2 decades now. Plus the actual mission designs have little relevance to the characters or strategy's thereof that were the opposition in the original. On top of that just plain sloppy mission design is present such as inclusion of production buildings for metal armor on maps where there are no trainable pikemen or swordsmen and no market availability for said armor.

Put simply, this is a version of the game made by people who seem to have never actually played the original. It is made like a "DE" would be for any other RTS, but not for Stronghold. Even just cursory input from someone remotely familiar with the game would've drastically improved this product.

Definetly recommended classic stronghold that has been brought to modern ERA, extra missions are a bonus and playing through the old missions is also fun.

Let me preface this by saying that I've played Stronghold since I was 4~ years old when it came out.

There is so much to say about this game, I'll try to say as much as possible while keeping to the point. I am a massive Stronghold fan, always have been, I think I've bought 5-6 or so copies of the game, be it for different Steam accounts, or gifts for friends, or buying it also on GoG etc. etc. I've always enjoyed and loved this game and it's a game I keep returning to and always will keep returning to.

Finally after 20 or so years Firefly have finally made the sensible choice of returning to their one working games in their IP. The thinking is sound, you iterate on the old product and you offer improvements in order to offer a more attractive product and get sales.

What does this remaster offer this time around? 

A new campaign. It's pretty good. The campaign itself does not warrant the price though in my opinion, so wait for a sale if you can. Part of the reason why I think it's not good enough is the fact that I find the level design to be lackluster at times. Stronghold is a game often described as "castle sim," revolving around building castles, but annoyingly enough I feel like most map designs heavily encourage people to just build a wall or set of fortifications between point A and point B to defend against enemy attacks, which to me does not encourage much strategic depth and thinking. It truly is a shame because the maps themselves often look great but the gameplay does not differ much from map to map when the only difference is "build a wall and some towers to block off this cliffside," "build a wall and some towers to block off this peninsula" or "build a wall and some towers to block off this mountain pass." I get that this might come off as nit picky but I can't help but feel like I expect more when we're paying for the development of this remaster.

New remastered graphics. I'm torn on these. This is subjective, but in my opinion the new graphics fail to capture the charm that the old game has. It may very well be due to the nostalgia of having played this game for 20 years, but it just doesn't feel right to me personally. However a point on the graphics that is not subjective is that they have not done a great job with the animations for some units. For whatever reason they chose to replace/slightly change the graphics of the swordsmen and the knights, which is fine (though me personally I thought the old ones were more charming, but again, that is subjective,) but what really stands out with them is that the framerate of these two units is simply way too high, and the movements of them completely lacks any sense of weight. I strongly prefer the look that the old swordsmen had for example, because they felt more powerful simply because they looked like they were heavy. The new swordsmen almost sort of look like they are sliding across the surface. The knights as well look like they are moving way too fluidly and unnaturally, and also they weirdly lean back into their saddles.

This remaster has multiplayer support. That's a big plus. Get it if your friends are nagging you to play with them, if you want I guess. If you can disregard the other points that I've already made.

This remaster also introduces a few new bugs. That is to be expected of course when the game is remade in Unity, but it's just a bit disappointing to see both your melee units ignore battering rams that could have been destroyed before they reach your walls. Same way that it is also disappointing to see a siege tower get destroyed, but still see enemy units use the "destroyed" invisible siege tower to scale your walls in a completely unfair way and kill your lord.

For these reasons I simply can't whole-heartedly recommend getting this game. I still recommend people to get the original when it's on sale, but if someone asked me "should I get Stronghold: Definitive Edition?" I'm probably gonna say no.

[h2]The legend has returned and is better than ever![/h2]

Stronghold: Definitive Edition is Stronghold 1 we all love, but vastly remastered in many ways to fit the modern standards. Refreshed visuals (they look gorgeous, by the way) and music; new features; Steam Workshop; multiplayer integrated with Steam; a lot of quality of life improvements; and many more... All of that without affecting the core mechanics of the game itself and, of course, its brilliant atmosphere that surely made a lot of older players fall in love with this game back in the day. Not to forget the fact that the game works like a charm.

This is clearly the best way to play and experience Stronghold 1. It doesn't matter if you played the older versions of the game in the past, or perhaps you may want to check out this fine classic at last. "Definitive Edition" is truly worth its name. It also reminds us that Stronghold 1 is not only the first video game of the well-known Stronghold franchise, but also that - even after all those years - its gameplay holds up as a great classic castle building simulator. And like I mentioned earlier, the Definitive Edition's improvements and new content, really make the difference, if compared to the older versions of the game. They allow players to experience Stronghold 1 in all its glory and in a pleasant way, fitting the modern standards.

Thank you, Firefly Studios, for remastering this game in such a fantastic way!

I really was excited about this game. I also actually played the first of the new campaigns. It's really not that special, but it is more optimized for new computers. No need to mess with the resolution. I also haven't really seen that many bugs aside from a few annoying ones like a rock being here, or not being able to build on top of bushes, but I now think the latter is intentional. 

The best parts of the "definitive edition" is that you can adjust more things control and hotkey related. They also changed other things like the main menu and designs of certain things. Most of the time, I don't even notice the difference between the improved designs of buildings and whatnot. The original campaign is basically the same, but the colors look like they were too defined and bright; however, while I prefer the original look for the cut-scenes and character portraits, I'll admit that the new look doesn't look terrible. It is strange how Sir Longarm and Lord Woolsack's portraits have a golden hue to them, but all in all it's not so bad. 

     The best things about this remaster is that you can zoom in and out more freely, adjust hotkeys as you like, and a grouping mechanic which is actually quite helpful- but don't use the number 9 option because you'll get those units stuck in that slot without being able to adjust it. I suppose they apparently added the Steam Workshop and such; but honestly, as a game, it's not much better, and the new content isn't worth it.

   There were times I would be in annoyed wonderment; like, why the heck can't I build stuff other than quarry's on top of the stone reserves? Where did such a dastardly idea come from? Why doesn't a Cathedral or Church add a small bonus like before? How come the new maps weren't that well refined? I can't build something in a perfectly well-enough sized spot because of a single-dot of uneven ground, rock, or bush? When was it that you couldn't build on top of bushes? Not trees, bushes of all things. How come my ranged units require so much micro-management at times? The original stuff is still just about the same or as good as in the original, but some stuff makes the game annoying.

    I finished the first part of the new campaign, but it's more of a pain than anything fun and engaging. The story is extremely lackluster, unfortunately the VA's performance is somewhat lacking, and the missions themselves are terrible. The maps used are more of a pain than not as well. The fighting on said maps are annoying because of the enemy troop placements, like they have two or three missions where you go through this maze-like map to get to the end. The first one wasn't so bad, but there was one where I almost wanted to just stop because of how bad the design and arrangements were. To be clear, the maps mostly weren't hard, they were just tedious and tiring. They say the new campaign is made for "veteran players", but it was such a pain and nothing like the original campaign. 

If you like more modern and adjustable, and maybe like anything and everything new from Firefly even if the new missions are just a pain and wearisome, then you probably won't care for this remaster's shortcomings. I would recommend just getting the original because it still has a lot to offer which is what most of this one is anyway, and it's quite a bit cheaper. I almost want to fully recommend it, but I didn't particularly enjoy everything that's new. More of a painful experience than a fun one regarding the new content, but I can't say the same for the original. I will always be glad for the original content. I wish I could give it a 3/5 stars kind of rating, or a neutral one. It's good, but essentially only because of what was already established beforehand. Some of the new stuff are nice, but not the campaigns.

I've never played this games growing up and I thought I should give it a shot. Assuming that this was polished, I was pretty disappointed with the result. The odds a far against you for most of the campaign missions. It's ridiculous that taxes is immediately a negative feature; No money = no soldiers, food, etc. I feel this game was designed by libertarians. The game is all about consuming your resources, while the town doesn't work to sustain itself. It's a complex version of a tamagotchi; more variables to work against to keep it alive.

I appreciate the graphical improvements to this classic game, though I wish there were a bit more in the way of new content added to this.  The original Stronghold was excellent, and what this adds, besides graphics, is a couple short campaigns.  I cannot think of anything else that was added.  I really wish there were an option to use multiplayer maps with bots, but that was not added in.  I guess I will have to hope we see Stronghold Crusader: Definitive Edition. tactics;
game mechanics at their core are the same as the legacy games (SH 1 and ST Crusader), but arrows feel like they are nerfed somehow; an archer/crossbow army is not the answer to all problems in this game as it used to be in the legacy games, so be careful of that in your tactics. 
By consequence; Macemen just became a whole lot scarier Lol; a unit of crossbowmen can no longer stop an equal force of macemen without breaking a sweat; no, the macemen will tank the crossbow bolts long enough to get to the crossbowmen and they will club them.
Spearmen are now actually useful and they can actually hold their own against better melee units when they outnumber them like 5 or 4 to 1. Can no longer just wade throw hords of enemy spearmen with a very small force of armored units like the legacy SH versions. 
In general: it gets some getting used to, but it feels more.. right. each unit in the game has its uses now. The Leather Army tactic (crossbowmen and macemen only) still worms well, but other tactics are just as viable now.

Economy: 
much more limited on where and how you place your mines and quarries, so a mining economy is impossible on most maps now. 
Ale is maxed out at 4 popularity, and religious buildings are all but useless and are now actually a hindrance as the peasants will "demand more" without you gaining any extra popularity out of it, and you will actually lose popularity if you delete them to switch economy later on, so just don't bother. 
Max tax is capped at 20 now, so no more 24 tax and max popularity perfection builds.
In general; the economy feels more limited and slower, but it is much more agriculture based, and this feels more realistic for the middle ages

Look, it's a pretty old game. I'm writing this review for you guys - not the game or devs. I'm writing it in the hopes that on those days when you just don't feel like playing the latest AAA (or indie) trending game, you might consider giving this classic a try. It really is worth the chance, and if you can get it for under 10 bucks, it's a steal. And I truly think most people will like this one a lot.

Like strategy games? Like City/castle builders? You need to buy and play this if you never have. And if you've played it in the past, you owe it to yourself to play it again. 

Is it the type of the game that will be your top ten favorite? No, probably not. But it absolutely will give you dozens to hundreds of hours of fun. It's virtually bug free, being from the era when games were completed before they were released. Everything works. Maybe the UI isn't super modern, the graphics (although updated since the original release) are mediocre, and the music is... the music is better not mentioned. The story line is lighthearted/silly and relatively simple. You're not going to find any masterpieces of story writing, or outstanding characters that you think of fondly 10 years from now. That's not what this game is, and it doesn't try to be.

What this game is, is a very straight forward city/castle sim and strategy game. You gather resources that you use to build your defenses, your industry, train troops, and keep your peasants happy. Nothing is super complex about the systems. There's no research trees, or requirements you need to reach to unlock things  (though the campaign unlocks new buildings, resources, and weapons as you progress). Build wood or stone walls towers and gates in any design you wish. Make multi-leveled defenses, and employ designs that are segmented and redundant to help fend off waves of enemies. Train archers, spear men, mace men, pike men, crossbowmen, swordsmen, and even mounted knights to defend your castle and settlement. If that's not enough break out the siege weapons like catapults, trebuchets, ballistas; and traps, boiling oil, and war dogs.

Some of the missions have you go on the offense, taking a limited number of troops and engines and assault the enemy, but for the most part, you're the one building and defending (in the campaign.) Additionally, there are some extra campaigns that add some newer features, buildings, and challenges - new maps, new tactics, and dozens of more hours of game time. 
If you decide you just want to design and build your dream castle and throw endless enemies at it to see how your design fairs, you can do that too. 

I hope that if you decide to give this one a chance you find it as much fun as I did. It really is a great game.

I first played Stronghold 22 years ago on its debut release, and as I sit here now reviewing the Definitive Edition I can’t help but feel immense pride to see Firefly Studios still actively flourishing – in the first 72 hours of release it had sold 100,000 copies and had a peak of 9,672 concurrent players on Steam.

Firefly was originally conceived in 1999, consisting of just two co-creators Simon Bradbury and Eric Ouellette, who spent their first two years together creating a game that aimed to merge both the City Builder and Real-Time Strategy genres. They accomplished this in 2001 with their first release – Stronghold, which released to critical acclaim and commercial success. The game became a surprise hit and due to its popularity led to several sequels including the fan favourite Stronghold Crusader in 2002. Both of these titles use a 2D isometric game engine which is comfortably the best way to experience the series, the Definitive Edition uses the Unity engine as a wrapper for the original game. 

The Stronghold series has been tried and tested over the years through different pathways, however sticking close to the original blueprint is what makes it (in my opinion) most grand. A blend of British charm and replayability made this series such an instant hit, combined with innovative castle building and visuals. 

The Definitive Edition enhances the original experience with remade artwork, modernised gameplay, high fidelity sounds and workshop support. The visuals are so crisp and smooth, like rewatching an 80s/90s program in HD. It’s absolutely fantastic. 

I will never tire from watching routine work processes in Stronghold – let’s take the art of making bread: watching workers harvest wheat crop, who then move the wheat to the keeps stockpile. The young workers then take the wheat from the stockpile and transfer it to the mill. Once flour is milled, the young workers take the bags of flour back to the stockpile. The bakers then pickup the flour and transfer it back to their bakery, where you’re able to watch them create food for the castle, before being placed into the local granary for storage/consumption. What I’m describing is the absolute charm of the game: watching the beautiful synchronisation of routine jobs throughout the castle is nothing short of scintillating and it is through this charm that makes the game richly excel. 

The Definitive Edition includes a new 14 mission campaign, along with a new historical ‘Castle Trail’ which sets 10 unique scenarios to delve into. The campaign itself was fine, I preferred the Castle Trail as it proved to be more challenging (I’m looking at [i]you[/i] Heuneburg) nonetheless my entire experience so far has been incredibly rewarding. Now that I’ve attained 100% completion, I look forward to the post-release schedule - at least two major free updates coinciding with paid DLC. [i]The Winter Update[/i] is set to contain new economic missions and maps, and will release alongside the [i]Swine's Bay[/i] DLC. [i]The Spring Update[/i] will include a new Castle Trail and maps, and is set to release alongside the [i]Valley of the Wolf[/i] DLC.

one of the missing point that i wanted badly was a proper new campaign with new animations and new story.

to give some context, one of the key thing that separates stronghold 1 vs stronghold 1 crusader (which made me like it to play both at times) is not only the environment (desert vs grassland-mountain), but is that in stronghold 1 there is CGI and animations, and a nice little storyline. Apart from the nostalgia and the memes, this game has nothing to offer in 2023. The pathfinding is horrible, probably even worse than in the original. Base construction is clunky. They didn't implement PvE skirmish against bots, which leaves you to play the campaign (or multiplayer).

The campaign has fun characters ("The Pig", "The Rat") but the missions are horrible. Most of them don't give you freedom how/where to build your castle, which is half of what the game is supposed to be about. The other half would be sieging an enemy's castle. However, in most missions the enemy has no fortifications or buildings on the map whatsoever. Instead, his units spawn at a pre-defined spot on one side of the map to attack you.

And if you thought the pathfinding of your own units was bad, you will learn that the enemy's units are even more stupid. "Sieging" your castle means that they just walk into range of your crossbowmen to be slaughtered. Successful attacks would require the AI to coordinate the movement of ranged, melee, sieging and supporting units, which it doesn't seem to be able to do. This makes the game so easy that you start to wonder why you're building fortifications at all.

To sum it up: Horrible remaster, even though I mostly like the updated graphics.

As much as I want to recommend this game, because I love the original and seeing this made me insta-buy because of nostalgia, I won't. There are some glaring gameplay bugs in this version, and I think Firefly could have easily playtested  this before they released to solve them. The fact that they didn't, AND the fact that they've already announced the 2 latest parts of the campaigns to be behind a paid DLC (making me have to pay more to get the entire story), makes me see this as a fast moneygrab and not worth my attention.

First the good:
2 new campaigns, awesome! I loved the new variety, and the scripted events on some "make your way through this map" missions were a fun addition to my stronghold experience.
Steam multiplayer looks like it works. This is a nice addition, but frankly, I loved stronghold for the singleplayer aspect so I didn't care much about this one.

Now the meh:
There are new sounds in this game. They are nice, but volumes are all over the place. Additionally, sounds are stereo by default. One of my ears is deaf, which means that if I play this game with a headset, I will not hear the announcer say that I am being attacked when my keep is to my right on my screen. Very annoying, but I get that they didn't put up this accessability as a priority. Sad though, that I didn't have this problem in the original game.
Click-Hitboxes of units are all over the place. it's harder than in the original to put units closely next to eachother, because you will probably select a unit you didn't want if you give a move order near it. This can be alleviated a bit using the new "modern" rts control scheme, where your RMB and LMB commands are shuffled a bit, but I shouldn't have to evade shitty hitboxes by changing my controls.
Improved visuals are nice in theory, but they look so much similar to the old visuals that there is not much reason to prefer these over the stronghold HD ones. 

Now the ultra-bad: 
There are some very dumb programming mistakes in this game that were not in the original.
First off, in the Jewel campaign with the Snake. They wrote some new AI for this game, making them prioritize gatehouses above "the weakest part in the wall". Unfortunately, when I do not build a gatehouse at all (because why would I want to walk to my signpost?) the AI... does not prioritize anything anymore. The enemy soldiers just stand still. If they feel REALLY motivated, MAYBE they will decide to stand still under your walls while getting pelted by your archers. Means I can win almost all "hold out until last battle" missions if I just wall off the signpost area. Very easy to spot bug, very dumb that they didn't catch it, very gamebreaking.
Additionally, there is a bug in the siege mode. If I select a map, then switch to attacking side, then back to defending side, and then start, I will have no army attacking me and I will instantly win the map. Probably the attacking army gets set to 0, because you can select a custom army now as the attacker in a siege. This means that at least it not unplayably broken, because if you do not switch between attacker/defender, the attacking army will be there like normal. Still, very dumb bug. Come on, firefly programmers, you can do better than this.

All in all, new campaigns are nice, but Firefly ffs hire some proper software testers.

A great castle builder. You can marvel at how your castle functions as every part of it moves around like a cog in a machine. The food that you will mainly eat comes from the wheat that must be processed first into flour before being fully transformed into edible bread. The position of every building also matters, as the worker needs time to go to the stockpile to fetch materials and return to their workshop. This will make you min-max the placement of every building (except for houses). The unit control itself is very simple, with only 3 behaviors that you can set a unit into: standby, defensive, and aggressive. What it lacks in unit complexity, it makes up for in scale, as controlling hundreds of archers is a normal occurrence. They also have a lot of options for combat outside of unit type. Elevation is important because your ranged units have better accuracy when placed higher; moats are important because you can better defend against sieges; oil pits are important because they could allow you to defeat far superior units using a lowly archer firing a burning arrow. Some of the RNG could be annoying, though. If you want to use either a catapult or trebuchet, just pray to God that they can destroy the target before emptying their magazine.

I’d absolutely recommend Stronghold DE to returning Stronghold players and new players alike. But before I write anything I want to address the elephant in the room; skirmish. There is not skirmish mode in Stronghold DE. There wasn’t a skirmish mode in the original stronghold, because there was not a Skirmish AI. The developers have said that is was unfeasible to create a whole new AI, and would instead focus on remastering graphics, animations, music, voice acting, multiplayer functionality, and adding new content. I get that. I forgive the game for not having skirmish mode, although I am admittedly disappointed like the rest of us. Even without skirmish, Stronghold DE offers a great amount of content. I’d wager if this game is successful, they will remaster Crusader, which had a skirmish mode.

The “remaster” aspect of this game is apparent. The animation and graphics quality has greatly improved. It offers a refreshing visual and audio experience for those coming back to the game, and realizing all the small details you may have missed due to the old graphics is a joy for those of us who grew up on Stronghold.  I’d recommend the game for this aspect alone, especially at the game’s low price point. 

It’s also worth mentioning the QOL improvements like barracks rally points and new hotkeys that modernize gameplay. 

There is ton of content. Not only do we have all the content of the original game, but we have a new military campaign and castle trail as well. Mission creation tools allow for community maps and missions to be shared, adding content. The road map promises two cheap DLC’s in the future, adding new campaigns for the cost of a cup of coffee.
 
Stronghold DE offers the perfect opportunity to relive this classic game, and adds more than just a new coat of paint.

Will preface this by saying I've spent literally high hundreds to thousands of hours playing Stronghold and Stronghold Crusader.  Starting in my childhood, through teenage years, university and now still as an adult.  I have basically done all there is to do in these games.  

For those of you who will be returning to this franchise, the redefined graphics, animations, framerate updates and overall re-make make this feel like a brand new game.  I found myself falling back in love with the micro-management of setting up a city, growing your resources and armies, and then just sitting back and watching the people of your castle work.  The reasons that I fell in love with these games in the first place decades ago.  There is so much familiarity with the setting, gameplay, soundtrack and animations that it feels right at home, but the upgrades make this feel new and exciting. 

If you are new to Stronghold this game will be an absolute treat, and I envy the feeling of experiencing this wonderful world for the first time.  It provides just enough to learn how to play the game, but requires the ability to micromanage economy, resources and military in order to really thrive.  

In about 25 hours I managed to wrap up the new Economic and Battle campaigns at Very Hard difficulty, and I found a few of the missions quite challenging.  If you are new to the game, they will be difficult!  But the ability to scale the difficulty makes this game great for all ages and skill levels.  Just enough challenge with a massive sense of reward at the end of every mission.  I took my time and just enjoyed the environment, the hustle and bustle of your castle. 

The only complaint that I have is sometimes when commanding troops to move or attack, you loose your troop selection when telling them to move to a location and have to reselect them and try again.  I don't remember this happening in the older games.  A very minor detail that doesn't effect the gameplay overall.  

I'll be able to spend another 20-30 hours on this game without feeling game fatigue or repetition setting in, meaning it is a 20-hr game for a seasoned vet looking to rip through just the new campaigns, or a 50+hr game for someone just looking to enjoy all of the options that are available: starting on the old campaign, continuing into the new campaigns, playing the Castle Trail, and enjoying the world builder and Castle Builder modes.  

I hope this convinces you to buy this game, as it is 100% worth it!!!

Not the best remaster, but neither the worst. All of the most annoying problems of Stronghold are still present here - the maps are still too small to have proper building freedom in multiplayer, any tower can still be manned with absurd amounts of soldiers by exploiting unit clipping. Townsfolk still annoy you by constantly blocking placement of buildings and walls. Mod support is still not a thing - Steam Workshop is for custom maps only. AI Skirmish isn't there as well, though the game has enough content to replace it, so the problem is not that critical.

Even though the remaster is not what I really expected, it still is the one and only Stronghold - a great game with lots of high quality and unique mechanics, wonderful art, sound and music and fantastic atmosphere. The campaigns are great, the siege / assault / economic missions are a very entertaining challenge.

All in all, a wonderful game, a must-have for sure. If anyone reading this haven't ever played Stronghold - you should definitely start here. The remaster doesn't change much but the core still is as great as it has always been. 

For those, who have already been playing Stronghold, however, I would advise to think before buying - even though the changes in this remaster are quite welcome, 99% of it is still the same game. If you are short on money and you already have Stronghold HD - I would not recommend it, buy something else instead.

[b]For people who played previous versions;[/b]
The graphic improvements are noticeable, but not drastic or jarring, the original charm is retained.
Original voices (50% of what made me love this game as a child) are still there.
The controls feel good, but unit patching is a bit hit & miss, AI are even more hit & miss.

The new content in the form of two short campaigns was... okay? Not terrible, just not very in depth.
One mission requires hitting several objectives quickly as regular 'easy' attacks from various signposts will be followed by one that will be very difficult to survive - even on the lower difficulties, and impossible if you weren't prepared for it (I wasn't, and I'm not sure the game really warns you about this well enough)
The two campaigns focus on the Rat & Snake's counties, but with much stronger unit comps than they seem to have in the original campaign. New intros & voice acting supports the new content.

Multiplayer as a built-in is nice, can be iffy with connectivity (Still easier than the old way), but lots of player made maps and a couple of updates have improved it so far.

[b]For people who haven't played previous versions;[/b]
If this is your first Stronghold game, this version is probably the best option as it's a little easier to play. 
Stronghold Crusader is often referenced as a better game - largely because the AI can build their own castles, which they CAN NOT in this game. The strength of Stronghold is the narrative campaign - which Crusader doesn't have.
A series of well sculpted missions with excellent writing & voice acting in their intros. The military campaign starts of easy and learning, introducing new elements, weapons and units in line with the story progression. 

It hasn't aged perfectly as a game, but I feel the main campaign holds up very well, even after years of re-playing, I didn't skip the intros, and thoroughly enjoyed them. 

The economic campaign sucks, but individual 'Invasions' and Economic maps are pretty fun, the sieges are cool, especially if you're familiar with the castles.

Many players of the original are disgruntled that this version hasn't imported features from Crusader, but that doesn't make sense to me personally, I got more or less what I expected, a polished, more playable (and OBS capture) version of the game from my childhood.

I do love Crusader, the skirmish missions, mercenaries and variety of AI lords, but can only hope that the success of, and support for Stronghold DE will lead to Crusader DE in the future.

Good morning, Your Lordship!

The moment has come for a classic strategy game to return in its rejuvenated form – "Stronghold: Definitive Edition". This game does more than just invite us to revisit childhood; it immerses us in a world of medieval castles and strategic battles, now refreshed with updated graphics and high-resolution support.

Graphics and Atmosphere
The “washed” graphics retain the familiar visuals but now appear more vibrant and detailed. Enjoy the stunning landscapes of your settlements and watch battles where every sword glistens in the sun. The soundtrack complements this atmosphere, transporting us deep into medieval adventures.

Strategy and Survival
Don’t forget about cheese – it’s a crucial part of your strategy and economy! Whether you focus on military actions or economic development, remember: a good stock of cheese is essential for your army's survival.

Multiplayer and New Missions
The multiplayer now functions flawlessly, allowing battles against friends and other players. New missions add freshness and challenge, prompting you to make innovative strategic decisions.

Nostalgia and Novelty
For those who remember the original game, "Stronghold: Definitive Edition" offers a dive into nostalgic memories. New players will discover a fascinating and thrilling world of medieval strategies.

Conclusion
And, of course, I must mention our faithful servant, always ready to report the latest events. His voice now sounds even clearer and more realistic, thanks to improved audio.

Verdict
"Stronghold: Definitive Edition" is not just a reissue; it's an opportunity to experience a classic strategy in a new light. This game combines the best of the past and present, creating a unique gaming experience.

Stronghold, the original BAFTA-nominated RTS castle sim, returns in a definitive edition that aims to recapture the essence of the classic. Set in medieval England, it offers a blend of strategic military campaigns and city-building elements. Despite its promising premise, the remake may not entirely live up to the expectations of fans of the original.

Overall Score: 6.5/10

Graphics/Visuals (7/10):

The updated graphics are a noticeable improvement over the original. However, while they are good, they don't stand out as exceptional. Sure, the fire looks prettier, but thats not exactly adding a lot of value when the game is missing features that were in the original (looking at you, skirmish mode).

Sound & Music (8/10):

The remastered music, returning voice talent, and the contributions of series maestro Robert L. Euvino are notable highlights, adding depth and nostalgia to the gameplay experience. The sound is honestly the best part of the remake.

Story & Narrative (7/10):

The storyline, with its focus on medieval England and the challenge of uniting the kingdom against various lords, remains engaging. However, it doesn't bring much new to the table in terms of narrative innovation. The new campaign isn't all that great as it lacks the castle building elements in a majority of the missions. It just gives you a set amount of troops and says "Good Luck!". The main feature of the game is all the building elements, but it shoots itself in the foot by giving you missions you can't use it.

Gameplay & Mechanics (5/10):

While the gameplay stays true to the original's spirit, the absence of the skirmish mode is a significant drawback, especially for players seeking a single-player challenge. If you aren't playing multiplayer, there is no way to simply build and fight another kingdom, which was the funnest part of the game.

Replayability & Content (6/10):

The game offers a decent amount of content with its military and economic campaigns. However, the lack of variety in game modes, particularly the missing skirmish mode, limits its replayability significantly.

Innovation & Originality (6/10):

While the game attempts to bring classic RTS gameplay to a modern audience, it doesn't introduce substantial innovations or improvements over the original, making it feel somewhat dated. While I get thats the point, when you bring an old game back with less features than it originally had, its gonna be a bad time.

Technical Performance & Optimization (10/10):

The game performs just fine. No issues.

Value (6/10):

For fans of the original, the game might hold some value at $15 USD, but the absence of key features and lack of significant updates may not justify the purchase for new players or those looking for a comprehensive RTS experience. You are better off purchasing a previous installment in the series. I can't help but feel like this is a bit of a cash grab.

Final Thoughts:

The definitive edition of Stronghold nostalgically revisits the classic RTS, but it falls short in delivering a fully satisfying modern remake. The absence of popular features like skirmish mode and the lack of significant new content make it a mixed bag. It's a game that might appeal to die-hard fans of the original for its nostalgia factor but could disappoint those looking for a something more. 

If I could give it a mixed review, I would, but I can't recommend the game in its current state.

[h1] 1.Graphics. Why was this done? [/h1]
- Compared to HD, the graphics don't look that much better. Moreover, after 15 minutes of gameplay, you completely forget which version you're playing. I deliberately opened both HD and the Definitive Edition for comparison. There's no noticeable difference, except HD costs 1 euro, and the Definitive Edition costs 15 euros.
- Furthermore, HD feels even better because the animations in the game are quite clunky. It's understandable for that time and that image quality. In the Definitive Edition, they slightly improved the image quality, but the animations remained the same, now they look out of place.
- The quality of the game environment is questionable. If before everything was clear - where the cobblestones are, where the trash is, and where the impassable cliffs are, now eyes hurt from mixed up picture. The environment now lacks consistency. It seems as if it's stitched together from assets of different games.
[h1] 2. Game Engine. The good old Stronghold. [/h1]
- Gameplay-wise, it's the same game, with the same bugs and the same imperfect engine. The game has quite a few bugs, although they are not critical:
-- Soldiers clip through the tower into the jagged wall and remain stuck there forever.
-- The stone quarry storage sometimes spawns on an inaccessible cliff next to the quarry.
-- Sometimes food producers don't see the granary and consider it inaccessible - you have to delete and rebuild it.
-- Another bug - order archers to shoot an area. When they have their bows drawn, order them to shoot at single enemy. If before they couldn't reach him or shot at him in the general area, now all arrows fly precisely to the target. Cheese as it is.
-- If you want to overcome a cliff and are allowed to build - construct a wall cell right on the edge - now you can build a staircase on both sides of the wall. And your farmers no longer need to make a detour through half the map to get to the warehouse.
That is not all, just what I have quickly recalled.
- The controls in the game are a kind of torture. You won't be able to select one unit from a crowd from a bird's-eye view - always 2-3 fighters will be highlighted. And selecting all units of the same type with a double click in this situation becomes impossible. If you're controlling a group of siege weapons - you'll often accidentally move engineers out of them because exiting the weapon and moving are done with the same right mouse button.
- Another topic is the game engine and the way range is calculated. As a player, I NEVER understand where and from where my archers can shoot. Sometimes I calmly shoot beyond the towers, sometimes I don't reach the point where I should theoretically hit.
[h1] 3. Game Engine. The good old Stronghold. [/h1]
Quality of the New Campaigns and Gameplay in General.
- In short, the new campaigns are like a slap in the face. The missions feel as if they were made by a child. Some missions are simply long and disrespectful of the player's time, while others are absurdly simple and feel like a joke. Out of the two campaigns, there are 2-3 missions that genuinely spark interest. The rest are unclear fillers.
- I'll note a positive point here - missions where you have to first capture a castle and then hold it are a good addition.
- I want to address the developers - you should prohibit engineers from pouring pitch while standing on the ground. Because any mission where the player has access to pitch turns into a circus. Just place 3-4 engineers with pitch near the sighpost, and the entire enemy army will burn obediently while the AI is on timeout.
- The AI in the game is generally weak. Stronghold is not a game about castle building. It's a game about building 3-4 large towers right next to the sighpost. While the AI is on timeout, archers destroy any army. The solution to this problem is simple - allow the construction of defensive structures only within a radius around the bastion.

[h1] 4. What conclusions do I want to draw? [/h1]
All the negativity outlined above is not really the fault of the developers but rather the legacy of the old game. We love Stronghold for some of its bugs and cheesy mechanics. However, in the updated version, I would expect more than just improved graphics.

I'm glad I got to experience this iteration of the game, but I don't believe it's currently worth the money, especially considering you can buy HD for 1 euro. What would I expect from a refresh of such an old game?

-Overhaul of the engine regarding range calculation.
-Display of shooting range.
-The ability to set formations for squads. Try stretching your archers into a line now - it's not an easy task.
-Improve the AI; it's currently a sad sight.
-In multiplayer matches, add the option to play against AI + the ability to complete multiplayer scenarios.

However, I have a feeling that the developers simply wanted to quickly make some money, so we may never see these improvements.

[h1]Age of Empires Overrated, Simcity Outdated, Stronghold Updated[/h1] 
This was my First Strategy game. 
I found it in an old Office supply store and got hooked the moment I loaded it up. If you ever played Age of empires or a city building game you'll enjoy this game for its combination of battling, defending, siege and economic building. 

[h1]Main Original Campaign[/h1] 
Same as original, good way to get back into Stronghold to enjoy it and learn for the first time. 
AI is as devastating as before, I managed to beat every level EXCEPT one (The Pig Siege) on Normal. 

[h1]Siege/Invasion[/h1]
One of my favourite modes where you play levels created by the developers themed around either defending or attaching complex Kingdoms. With the addition of Workshop you'll pretty much never run out of these. 

[h1]Economic Campaign/Missions[/h1]
Sim City Builder game mode, LOTS of fires, LOTS of Plague, LOTS of Rabbits. 
Fun, Casual fun whilst also difficult without a strategy at times. 

[h1]Multiplayer[/h1]
Laggy, Doesn't show servers after updates (last time I looked it was fixed though)
Ignore and Pass. 
[i]Note: 2 Achievements are connected to Multiplayer, Start a server with the achievement in the title, set teams of 4v4 and have one team leave or just wait for them to leave[/i]


[h1]Whats New?[/h1]
The Definitive Edition adds a number of new things that old players will enjoy and enjoy like coming back for another round such as new graphics which look AMAZING, Entirely New Campaigns and workshop capabilities for endless scenario's which I will outline separately below.

[h1]The Jewel Campaign[/h1]
Two small campaigns with around 7 missions each. These are Campaigns where you fight the Rat or the Snake and there are different themes to these levels such as Build and Defend, Siege or Survive, free captured troops and get to the objective. It's fun and new. 

[h1]Castle Trail[/h1]
This is a series of 10 Siege or Defend the Castle levels with no time limit like the campaign.
It's effectively a playlist of the Siege/Invasion game mode levels with a text introduction of a real world event.

[h1]9.5/10[/h1]
[i]- Age of Empires Meets Simcity[/i]

Disclaimer: I love the original Stronghold, bought the HD version and immediately this one too. I spent countless of hours, enjoying the previous games, but this one is definitely a major letdown. At least, objectively speaking. The original game is almost a quarter century old, and always had some shortcomings. Glitching issues, pathfinding problems and such. In the early 2000s we easily overlooked this, but it's shortcomings became painfully obvious when I played the game again.

Which means, that FireFly Studios didn't really do anything meaningful with the game, just gave it a graphical facelift and that's all. I didn't expect major overhaul, fully expanded campaign and such, but to be frank, not even minimal effort was put into this game.

- Unit pathfinding is still abysmal and seemingly at random, especially in larger groups.
- Moat filling is still annoying, units stretch out as wide as possible, exposing themselves to danger.
- Even with aggressive setting, archers/crossbowmen sometimes fail to shoot at targets, you have to micromanage them.
- Last, but not least, shitstain mission design stayed. Hello Mission #15, Carving the Path. Here, you can only cheese your way through, exploiting AI and map design like in the originals. I mean seriously, what would it take to fix the map here and there to give an angle to attack?

I mean, if you just want to play the old Stronghold with a bit of graphical facelift, then go for the game by all means. If you expected a bit of nip and tuck to streamline gameplay experience, then it's not the right one.

The classic strategy game is back, and in a good way. 
For those who never played it - its a medieval real time strategy with a focus on castle on castle siege combat. Its quite compact and easy to understand with its basic production chains and simple units, but has good skill expression through optimizing speed and position of everything you manage. There is no tech tree bullshit or special ability showdown. All players have access to same tools.
Its very atmospheric and charming despite its simplistic isometric visuals, with lovely Medieval England aesthetics, great music, sound design and voices. 
There is a decent variety of content and challenge - you got the main story, siege missions, economic missions and free build. There is no PvE skrimish setup like they had in Stronghold Crusader, but they never said it would be added, so its just a bit of a shame.
Regardless, now that its plugged into Steam Workshop, for just 15 bucks you get a great RTS experience that can be great fun for either those evenings after work or gathering friends for some PvP on the weekend

To start with, Stronghold is an amazing game. It was 20 years ago and still is today. That is... If the design works for it. The Definitive Edition mostly leaves intact what made the original game so outstanding, and the new visuals are definitely nice for the most part. So far so good.

The lack of a Skirmish mode like a lot of users pointed out isn't really the issue here. While it's nice to had it backported from the sequel Stronghold Crusader the game could easily do without that provided the Singleplayer content excels over it. And here's the thing. The real problem is what got added into the game, or what which didn't get changed.

The main campaign of 21 missions is awesome... But it has 3 awful missions in it centered around you commanding forces to take over a castle. While the missions aren't really that hard on Normal and still fair and doable on higher dificulties it's just an annoying nightmare to deal with those 3 siege missions even on Easy. They're totally not fun in the slighest and you're going to have to rely on an insane amount of saving and loading to get through (in comparison the rest of the missions can just be easily cleared without saving). It's completely out of contrast. While that was always part of the original game too it's a missed opportunity the devs didn't do some proper playtesting. How about considerable more troops, or fewer traps and forces for the opponent on Easy. That's what Easy is for.

There's also the economic campaign. It's fine and fun in it's own right, but it has some extremely annoying design going for it. Most hurdles thrown at you come in the form of events, like fires in the fourth mission. Not only erases it all your building in a blink of an eye, but your popularity just nosedives below 50 in a matter of seconds, meaning you have no way to get back up. Especially if your grannary goes out of stock too. The thing is... These are events. You could build water wells to quench the fires but it has to be one of the most useless buildings there is. Forget about trying to clear out the fires in time. Since the events occur at set intervals you keep making saves, and optimize for the best outcome prior to the fire starting. Bandits are fun too. Not because the bandits itself are that much of a hassle but because they obviously have to impact your popularity too. And they raze every structure in your path, and you can forget about your own forces making it in time unless you already had towers and walls set up in time.

Speaking about bandits... There's a two new smaller campaigns added into the Definitive Edition... And I feel mixed about it. When it's just a normal mission, it's fine for the most part, but I don't get for example why they rely so much on the economic-style campaign events such as bandits and fires as well. The original campaign didn't do that. And to make things worse, about one-third to half of the missions are siege missions... Yes... The exactly kind of missions you hate so much. It doesn't help that Stronghold doesn't have the cleanest gameplay to control your army with. There's no Attack Move for example like in Age of Empires II. Melee units don't tend to position them in front of your archers. Stuff like that. While none of this was an issue for me during the regular campaign, it does become an issue when mission design makes it it's core.

The two new campaigns also lack the same interesting storytelling the original campaign had. While the storytelling was nothing groundbreaking, it was charming with figures such as Sir Longarm, Lord Woolsack and the four villains. Showing the map of England (thank goodness my language sticks the default England map) shifting it's balance of control was already one of my smaller pleasures when playing Stronghold back then. The new campaigns? Forget all of this. Just a background with some scrolling texts. You don't even get to see in the mission overview which new features you got access to in that mission. It just links to the guide now instead. This was another one of those smaller things that added up to the experience.

Half of the original campaign is mostly focused on these invasion missions where you build up your fortifications and hold out for like 3 or 4 waves of attacks. And while these type of missions are generally fine and fun they generally don't last long enough in the 2nd half of the campaign. Don't bother trying to set up a whole infrastructure. By the time you done so the final wave has already started. The problem is that once you reach the second half of the campaign your ability to make more complex infrastructures increases too, yet... These missions last just as long, except with stronger and more enemies. It's best to just focus on the essential, boosting your popularity through good things, raise the taxes and buying the weapons from the Market. Producing them yourself just takes too long in missions this short. Maybe this was always the case, but I felt like the original campaign could have been rebalanced here and there. Especially with the mission you have to defeat the Snake you notice why there isn't a Skirmish mode in this game. The AI controlling the Snake is practicially braindead and all challenge in that mission mostly comes from invasions from the Pig at set intervals.

There's also some other stuff here and there that doesn't make sense. Why aren't Black Monks recruitable anymore from cathedrals? Did I miss something? Was boosting popularity through religion always that useless? Even with a dozen chapels you barely boost it. Do the townfolk always get in the way when I want to place buildings? Why are minor obstacles on the terrain such a problem now to build structures upon? Especially if you get into missions with barely any space to build. Why do my towers and gates instantly tear down when a new invassion happens if I build them too close by? The game already prevents you from building too close to signposts, so why do they get torn down instantly when I am allowed to build?

It's just a shame the original Stronghold couldn't had been better than this. You probably don't want to buy the two new DLCs if their quality is more of that of the new Jewel campaigns in this versions. I feel like a Stronghold Crusader: Definitive Edition would have gotten away much better with it even if it had the same lack of polished fine-tweaking in some areas and meager new campaigns. It has a Skirmish mode at least and given they keep things as they are, even if only for the Skirmish Trials it would had been an absolute positive.

Before I end this on a sour note. I really love Stronghold, and for the price this Definitive Edition is sold at you can't really go wrong with it (even better when on sale). What's there to love about Stronghold is still there, and even if it's only the original campaign it's still very much worth it (if you can resist slamming your keyboard trying to do those siege missions that is). You just need to know what you're getting into: a singleplayer campaign experience, which is perfectly fine. I just wished some more attention was given to the new content and the game was a bit more rebalanced. Some missions are simply too easy. Others too short. Others completely sucks. And others are just too frustating through it's events.

Stronghold was the first game I ever played on PC, and I am very passionate about it. Whenever I went back to it I was sad about the fact that the software is rapidly aging, and is technically no longer on par with other titles in the genre.
You can imagine my pleasure when DE was released. It fixes this exact problem, keeps the game very close to the original, and adds a lot more content and quality of life improvements, all at a considerably very cheap price point.
If you're a fan of the old Stronghold, you will enjoy this. If you're a fan of RTS games and are looking for something unique with the feel of a 90s indie game, this is for you. If you're a fan of medieval history, if you like economic simulations, or a great historical soundtrack, this game is also for you.
However, if you expect AAA quality release or the revolution of RTS gameplay, this game won't satisfy you.

This game is incredible! While I never played the original, I have always been a huge fan of Stronghold Crusader and moderately a fan of the other Stronghold entries. It's the most like Crusader, and I mean this as a huge positive, both games have similar/same animations, characters, units, and music. The feel this game, and Crusader, capture is unlike any other game in the genre. You do not get games with this much charm, unique and smooth gameplay, or music as good as this. This is Stronghold done right! I love the updated graphics and how smooth this game runs!

I am hoping the positive reviews and success of this definitive edition show Firefly that Crusader would be just as much, if not more of a success! I also hope it highlights how much Stronghold 1 and Crusader features are valued while they create their next big Stronghold title.

I do have some complaints:
1.  No Skirmish mode - The original also did not have this mode, but this mode is arguably the mode that keeps players playing the longest and allows more replay ability, especially for those who don't like playing against real players online.
2. No AI in multiplayer - There is no option to face AI in a multiplayer match, only real players. This just stopped at least 2 people I know from buying the game. I wonder how many others? As I mentioned above, there are players who do not like playing against real players, and having AI in multiplayer would have allowed the game to reach a larger audience and as well add more replay ability.

I love this game, I can't wait to complete the campaign and all the addicting challenges Stronghold is so good at, but coming from Crusader, which had skirmish and the option for AI in multiplayer matches, I felt disappointed that I will inevitably complete this game and have little reason to return once I finish the missions. Whereas if it had those features, I'd play this for years with my sister. I am hoping they update to add one or both of these features, but I do not have my hopes too high.

All in all, it's a great and true remaster of Stronghold 1. If you're a fan of the original and/or Crusader, pick this up and play! Show the developers your support for this incredible gem of a game.

In my opinion, this definitely takes me back to the good ole' days of this game, however, Firefly needs to do some more work. I feel really bad giving this a bad review but the game needs to be fixed. I will be happy to change my review once the product owner and dev team fix a few things and add some additional features. 

Here's what Firefly needs to do in order to give fans a Minimum Lovable Product:

1. Multiplayer games ABSOLUTELY NEED TO SHOW PING - we are almost in 2024 and playing games with people far away. Showing ping will prevent us from starting games with laggers/bad connections. That is a quick patch/fix and will improve the experience of many players. It may even solve the lag issue if we prevent it in the first place.

2. Allow buildings to be placed where peasants/soldiers are in the space. Modern RTS games allow this and it shouldn't be too hard to code an update.

3. The developers need to figure out why there is still bad lag and drop outs even after recent patches. There are many RTS games where this isn't an issue in 2023 so please figure it out and investigate. A re-release means you actually work to re-release and modernize code. If the lag is a player host issue, figure out a way to improve the code and make it more efficient.

4. Multiplayer staging screen should show map download progress indicator to both players and admin

5. Multiplayer needs more options as to what is permitted/not permitted. It should allow the admin to turn on/off mangonels, onagers, certain infantry weapon classes, walls, etc. otherwise everyone is just working off of honor system/a gentlemen's agreement

6. Multiplayer needs to add an option of PT (Peacetime) in the game so nobody can attack until X min (20 min, 30 min, 60 min, etc) 

I love the game but you can't just put out a game 20 years later and try and collect holiday gift money without "modernizing" the experience.

i can only say that this is an amazing remake. The graphics are very clean and were upscaled so you can see much more details as in the original, but the visual style of Stronghold is still preserved. Several quality-of-life updates make the gameplay more comfortable, like seeing a small arrow as an indicator if your popularity changes, or enabling right clicking orders for the troops.

Essentially, this is Stronghold 1 with all its contents and some more, like new campaigns, workshop support, achievements. I can recommend this for veterans and new players. Good Job Firefly.

CONS:
-No skirmish against AI (Which Stronghold 1 also did not have to be fair)
-No local LAN-Mode, which is bad for people like me who like to participate in LAN-Parties (Yeah they still exist)

The only reason this review is negative is to the get devs attention - the pathfinding bugs are baffling and really irritate. Also the issue with ambiguity which fields are traversable leads to rage-inducing issues with imprecise walling - especially close to the map edge. The AI is also weirdly exploitable (it seems that once the AI orders units somewhere it will calculate path once, and won't recalculate it regardless of what happens in the meantime)

There wasn't this much pathfinding issues in the original (I don't recall the state of AI, so no argument for comparison here). The readability always was an issue, but I feel it could've been solved (or improved) in the remaster.

All in all if you like the fantasy of building and sieging medieval castles, it is an excellent game to pick up - but it does show it's age in the abovementioned ways so have that in mind.

In general, it was difficult for me to make a choice between a positive assessment and a negative one for the game.
I will not list the advantages because if you played the original edition, then you already know them.
And now to the advantages of the publication itself. The very beauty of the reissue is the updated graphics, new missions, the addition of online battles. Everything.
Now for the cons. The translation and voice-over jambs have not been fixed (I'm talking about the version with Russian voice-over). The new missions suffer the same problem as other new missions in other re-releases and games of the series.
1. Plot: it happens when the devil understands and only ruins the main plot of the game
2. The missions are not that difficult, but in some moments it causes irritation even at normal difficulty (I played at very high and this is even more noticeable).
Now I'll move on to the online game. In an online game, you won’t find anyone after a couple of days of the re-release being released, and this is a bad signal for the game.
TO SUM UP: Despite the significant disadvantages of the re-release, I still believe that you can turn a blind eye to them due to the fact that the re-release adds features and network play that were not in the original, but all this was in other parts of the series. That is, this re-release makes a demo version of the game and also a series of games (yes, initially stronghold was just a test of the idea itself, which, as we all know, reached the general public), and puts the original game on a par with its successors. So I decided to give the game a positive rating.

Перечислять плюсы я не стану по причине того, что если вы играли в оригинальное издание, то вы и так их знаете. 
А теперь к плюсам самого издания. Сама прелесть переиздания состоит в обновленной графике, новых миссиях, добавлении сетевых сражений. Всё.
Теперь по минусам. Косяки перевода и озвучки так и не исправили (говорю это про версию с русской озвучкой). Новые миссии страдают теме же проблема, что и другие новые миссии в других переизданиях и играх серии.

Теперь перейду к сетевой игре. В сетевой игре вы фиг кого найдёте уже спустя пару дней выхода переиздания, а это плохой сигнал для игры.

Так что я принял решение поставить положительную оценку игру.

        [td]　
　The Stronghold game had the best castle simulation gameplay I had ever played. There's no other castle simulation game that keeps me coming back and spending hundreds of hours like Stronghold does. It's an RTS game with main features such as villagers doing their work with amazing animations and progression, unlike many other RTS games that often involve going back and forth without achieving much. Stronghold breathes life into the castle simulation genre.

　Seeing your kingdom progress from nothing into a grand European castle was the best view you had back in the 2000s. If you're familiar with SHC, you know that this game only uses 'Crusader' units, which actually forces you to go through a building process, search for resources, set up military workshops, collect tax money, and then build units. For me, it does feel a bit slower than SHC, not to mention that event missions, economy, and food can pose a pretty decent challenge. But hey, I had the original Stronghold and never finished it due to hardware optimization issues, so gameplay-wise, it's fine!

For more than 20 years, Stronghold has held steadfast to its RTS niche amongst the Starcrafts, Age of Empires and Command & Conquers of the world. Thus it is only fitting that it, too, now finally enjoys the luxury of a definitive edition.

For many of my generation, this was one of their first real PC games and the franchise is still beloved to this day. Playing it is ageless fun.

I can't really comment on the MP side of things (Coop, Bots, Skirmish) because I was never into that. However, I don't really see how something that was never part of the original game could warrant a negative review.

From what I can tell, Firefly Studios are dedicated to adding more content in the future which is very much welcome. At the time of writing I've already finished the new Rat and Snake campaigns which I thoroughly enjoyed. Looking forward to the Pig and Wolf DLCs!

I'd like to preface this by saying that the original Stronghold is my favourite game of all time. I would buy it for £10 from Game 20 years ago and when that CD would get too scratched or I'd lose it, I'd buy it again. And again. And again.

Stronghold: Definitive Edition is the exact same game I re-bought those 20 years ago; warts and all. It runs to a modern standard, it retains it's unbelievable charm, it's challenging and I absolutely love it... but, it's a game from 20 years ago. 

Multiple times I've snatched victory from the jaws of defeat by the foolishness of the attacking AI:
- Spearmen entering my keep to attack my lord only to leave and attack spawning peasants while my archers decimate them.
- In the mission where you try to truce with de Puce (that rhymes), the mangonels were built in the valley and were unable to pathfind to the walls correctly, simply marching right up to them and getting peppered with arrows.
- You can cheese missions by building defences as close as possible to the signpost. When the enemy spawns they will stand and take arrow fire until the scripting kicks in to make them move.
- An attacking army which should just rush the throne, stops to break down palisades - even under enemy fire.

I feel bad giving a game and series I love so much a thumbs down but I just know if I wasn't wracked with nostalgia this would be a regrettable buy from me. I was very on the fence about this rating. The price is very, very fair. I commend FireFly on not ripping the arse out of it. Their roadmap is fantastic too and, admittedly, I have't tried any of the new offerings in this... but it boils down to the fact I already own Stronghold: HD and if I launched this the experience and gameplay would be identical.

Good and bad at the same time.
Graphics: When I first played the new version, I did not see that much difference to the older versions. But then I started the HD-version: Oh my, what a difference! Crystal clear graphics instead of blocky ones. It also workes on Ultra Wide displays without black borders!

The gameplay is good and bad at the same time:  Building a castle is fun and the economy works as intended without much flaws. But the fighting system? If you select archers and an enemy just out of reach: They don't go to him, no, they just say "I cannot reach him". This is mediocre, but ok when defending a castle, but attacking one this behavior breacks your balls. As well as the spearmen etc. If set on aggressive, they attack walls first bevor attacking the enemy. So if you breached a castle, they will not go after the attacking foes on the towers, they will attack the next wall. If you manually select them to attack a foe, they might kill him and even then, they start hacking the walls. This is so frustrating!

But year, if your focus is more on defending than on attacking, this game is still one of the best.

It is not easy being a stronghold fan.
For over 20 years now we watched Firefly trying to capture even a glimpse of the brilliance they captured with stroghold and stronghold crusader, the latter of which released in 2002. 
Fore two decades we bought title after title hoping they would have returned to that original spark that put their studio on the map, only to be disapointed time and time again. 
We have experienced everything from from buggy titles, ugly graphics, dysfunctional clients, broken AI and unfinished releases and compared to all those set backs stronghold definitive edition is at last a step in the right direction. 
However Firefly chose to call this remaster a definitive edition, yet there is precious little definitive about it. 
They had 20 years, 20 years to get this right and yet we are still confronted with the same frustrating bugs, from units disappearing to broken AI, on top of gaining an entirely new issue on the side of online functunality, which is practically none existent. 
Compared to the features and improvements of other companies definitive editions, which they deliberately invited comparison too when they labeled it as such, this is a sad excuse for another round of cashing in on Stronghold Nostalgia.

This game is perfectly serviceable as a remaster, it is an accurate to the original and makes notable improvements in areas  like aspect ratio. So I am not gonna tell die hard stronghold fans not to enjoy it, after 20 years of worse and worse stronghold titles, this game must appear like drops of a water in the uncaring desert, but for anyone that looks for a deeper  truely defintiive experience they are probably better off just playing a modded version of crusader or just save the money and keep playing stronghold for what little this game offers in extra content: two very short campaigns and a campaign trail, which is again more frustrating than fun due to broken AI. But then again maybe you just appreciate the slightly prettier pictures, although if you want to see how far the love and dedication has fallen just look at what they did to your poor advisor (and yes I know you can turn his appearance back to the old version, its just sad that I felt the need to do that, which again I find runs contradictory to what a definitive edition should stand for).

If you like Stronghold, you'll like the game. Unfortunately, this seems more of a cash grab. Minimal content and revised graphics. Would love if there was more DLC where you could have different campaigns/scenarios.

I played a little bit of the game before writing this review. It is[b] definitely playable[/b], runs pretty fluent on my system and gives a "similar" feeling, just like the original.  [i] (why similar you'll see in my list below)[/i]

Was running the German version on 1440p@144hz, so I'm not sure if the audio issues also occur in the English one.

[h3] Current Issues [/h3]
[list]  
    [*] I have a keen eye for detail, and one of the most bothersome things are[b] the oversharpened [/b]textures, especially on buildings like the hunting hut. The old game had one thing it nailed perfectly: a harmonious design throughout every visual aspect of the game. I've already noticed a lot of mirrored textures (e.g., the recruitment building HUD) and, as mentioned, oversharpened buildings or units. They don't blend well together, which I hope will be fixed because this is probably the first time I can't stare at my screen for a long time without feeling exhausted, and I'm 26.
    [*] The dialogue volume decreases throughout the game while other sounds remain at the same level.
    [*] I really dislike having to zoom out every time I start a new mission or map. It always starts at the most zoomed-in option.
    [*] The UI elements of the cursor also scale down with the UI scale setting, which shouldn't happen. Please let me change the HUD of the game and the cursor elements separately.
[/list]

Other than these issues and some strange animations, it is a good definitive edition and definitely worth the price. I sincerely hope they won't abandon this game after a few months because I see similar potential to what AOE 2 is right now.

I grew up on the original Stronghold and Stronghold Crusader. I played Stronghold Crusader competitively in a clan on GameSpy Arcade between the ages of 14 and 17, so believe when I say I played the living HELL out of Stronghold games back in the day.

This is not a "definitive edition" for Stronghold games as a whole, it's a slightly updated version of the original Stronghold only. If you, like me, preferred Stronghold Crusader, this will be a disappointment. There are elements missing that ought to be there. When I saw "Stronghold DEFINITIVE Edition" my initial thought was "oh good, they made an updated, combined version of the old Stronghold gameS (plural)," but that is not what this is.

A "definitive" edition should have the games defining feature, which was skirmish mode for most people who played it. Being able to play multiplayer with fun AI enemies and allies included was what defined Stronghold games for me, and that being absent from this game really kills it, to be honest. I had very high hopes, and they were not met. The updates that are there are fairly negligible. It's essentially just an improved graphics version of the original Stronghold. I'd rather the original graphics with updated features and AI over this.

A great REMASTER of the good Stronghold game.
Improved graphics, music, animations, mechanics, etc.
New campaigns (with more coming soon), focusing on both economic and military aspects. Split in multiple categories you can play the economic ones or the military ones.
There are also separate missions (both economic and military).
There are sieges and invasions, where you can assault and/or defend historical emplacements (castles from all over Europe).

-- YOU CAN CHOOSE WHETHER TO ATTACK OR DEFEND IN EACH ONE.
--- MOD SUPPORT. For example, invade Helm's Deep from The Lord of The Rings.
The Sandbox/Freeplay is still here, and made better through additional parameters you can configure before playing AND DURING YOUR PLAY (PRESS F1 FOR THE MENU).

Your name is spoken on launch once set (and can be changed later-on. For example I am welcomed with 'Good Morning, Lord Daniel'. Depending on time of day it changes which is amazing.
-- They also have that for voicelines during missions and actions such as 'Surrender, Lord Daniel?' when I wish to surrender in a match.
DOWNSIDE: There is no skirmish in Multiplayer (yet), so you can only do PVP, not PVE.
UPSIDE: Singleplayer there is Freeplay, siege, siege that, invasion and custom maps.

Multiplayer works flawlessly now, you don't require Hamachi anymore because it is steam steam multiplayer now.
Built-in Map editor, with upgraded functionalities etc.
Built-in Steam Workshop support.
New unit: Monk. Imagine macemen but Religious.

~~~~

Difficulty:
The game is made by veterans, for veterans. The missions are already challenging on Medium Difficulty. This is done by changing starting units and resource amounts, or additional random events or enemy mechanics.
