I really wanted to like this game. I've heard such good things about the series but for some reason it always passed me by. I've tried to play some of the re-releases over the years but could never get them to run properly. So I was excited to try this out.

UI is super important to me in games, especially anything to do with strategy or building. And this is... not good. I have to click on my granary to see how quickly my food will run out. Placing gates within walls is painful - you can't rotate buildings, instead you have to choose one of 4 possible orientations in the building menu. And aligning them to my walls was a process of trial and error. 

There's no way I could find to speed the game up, so the early parts of missions run super slow while you build up your stockpiles. There's no control groups for units. The final straw for me was when my woodcutter walked halfway across the map to chop down trees, instead of walking to the forest right next to his hut, and got ripped apart by wolves.

If you played this back in the day then you'll probably love it. It's a handsome remaster in many ways, and you'll probably feel right at home if you're already used to it's quirks. But it didn't do enough to hook me in and the frustrations quickly piled up.

My favorite addition is that you can now build troops in batches by holding down shift (5 units), or Ctr (as many as available).

Also holding Ctr while building siege weapons allows you to build multiple tents instead of having to go back into the menu each time.

Also the ability to add troops to pre-existing "squads" (the 1-10 groupings). Really awesome for big attacks with multiple unit types.

Also holding Ctr while clicking a building will allow you to immediately start building the same building without having to go into the menu

Also auto-trading with the market is a nice late-game addition when the resources are rolling in and it becomes a hassle to buy/sell things when trying to manage a siege.

First off, I have well over 100hrs in Stronghold Crusader HD + Stronghold Extreme, go knows how many hours I have if you count hours played not on Steam. This isn't the game I love, that's for sure. First off, where the hell are the Arabic armies? There units and lords simply just don't exist as far as I've gotten. The campaign missions are god awful. You are either stockpiling resources while they are sending units to kill you, or trying to survive waves of enemy attacks. There are very few missions where it is you versus an actual enemy to kill, and when you do your just commanding a siege, not constructing a base to create an army. Adding to that, you almost never get to construct your own castle. There is always a significant prefab, if not entirely.

Finally, why the hell is there no free versus battle where you can select computers, their difficulties, starting positions, etc? Everything is some shitty mission or you have to design your own.

There are also some other more minor gameplay "annoyances", such as when you're moving units up to elevated surfaces, if you're playing in the flattened view the green location markers are always floating above since it can't seem to properly account for the 3D to 2D locations.

If you're looking to play Stronghold Crusader, this ain't it. Just go play that.

Been playing Stronghold since I was like 8 years old. I'm 32 now. This was the game that started my love for RTS games. Plus, the original, or rather, Stronghold HD held up really well. And personally, I have never been a big stickler for graphics so I wasn't sure if a "definitive edition" of this classic game was necessary. But man this is DEFINITELY worth it!

For starters, the graphics and animations are all updated and they look great. So thats all well and good, but what really got me excited was all the new content and modern quality of life features! 

A whole new campaign (I forgot the name of) A kingmaker trail! Which was a mode that was introduced with Stronghold Crusader. I haven't tried it yet, nor the new campaign but I am very excited for their inclusion. 

Another update for this version is Steam Workshop support! The workshop support has done a lot for Stronghold Warlords and I can't wait to see some of the content that people come up with for it.

On top of what was there before, we get all this new content plus a road map with a lot of exciting stuff planned! And these guys have had a good track record of sticking to their plans (At least they did with Warlords when it comes to the roadmap). 

All in all I would highly recommend! Especially for the price, its a solid RTS and a legendary classic, only made better by new controls (WASD camera control/ Q&E rotating screen) that you can choose between "Classic" and "Modern" controls, which was very nice to see. 

Only issues I have found so far are audio issues. When you get a "Message from your scribe" and the message proceeds to play at the same time. Which is a minor issue that will probably be patched soon.

I would be lying if I said I wasn't sad to not see a skirmish mode V AI. The original didn't have it until Crusader, but there is a lot of new content that wasn't in the original game already so I am very excited about that. Even though they don't mention skirmish v AI in the road map, I am still hopeful, and again, excited for what is coming in the road map.

TL:DR If you are a longtime Stronghold fan and love the original game GET THIS ONE! It has everything you use to love with even more content and planned DLC for the Pig and Wolf with the original Voice Actors! Very exciting stuff. If you are new to Stronghold this is a great place to start with the updated graphics and modern controls and QOL features! Highly recommend!

As a huge Stronghold fan that has been into the series for a long while, seeing Stronghold DE's announcement trailer was something magical. Words can't explain how hyped I was for the release. Two demos and a full version later, I quickly realized and accepted that things are not so colorful with this remaster.

It's not another "no skirmish" complaint. It may be an unpopular opinion but skirmish mode was always overrated for me. Original Stronghold is a mix between a Castle Sim and an RTS, not just the latter - it's not built for rapid action, and people that complain about the lack of this mode knew perfectly well what they were buying. The problem lays in a lot of different aspects.

For starters - let me talk about the promised DE's features:

[b]Remastered Visuals using original artwork:[/b] I'm happy with that, somewhat. Firefly delivered a solid visual update, but not without it's flaws. The graphics instantly lose all their charm after zooming out, when they become very grainy, or sometimes even when casually moving around (Anti-aliasing issue?). It's a shame, cause the visuals otherwise are really nice, but as someone who uses the zoom-out feature a lot, it quickly becomes annoying and even nauseating.
[b]Remastered Music:[/b] I have not noticed a single piece of music that was touched in any way. Maybe it's for the better, cause the original soundtrack is pretty iconic and just good, but why advertise that then?
[b]Returning Voice Actors:[/b] Two of them, to be exact, which is alright, but it's worth mentioning that Firefly didn't reach out to fulfill that promise in other countries. Only english dub has that feature, so whoever from a non-english speaking country hoped to hear their version's old VAs will likely be left disappointed.
[b]Upgraded Characters:[/b] Feels like the biggest lie from all the promises, even counting the music one. It feels like the only real character that got an upgraded look was Sir Longarm, and even about that I'm not so sure. It's just plain AI upscaling for all the little videos you see on the radar or story mode, which sometimes does it job in some way, but in majority of cases is just absolutely hideous (For example, the blacksmith looks like he's been working a while in a highly-radioactive environment). Firefly did explain that quite a bit of old resources got lost or are not compatible with modern tools, but why then would you boast about artificially upscaling characters and calling it a day like it's actually any impressive or good? Other seemingly lost assets such as defeat/victory screens were really well remade, why wouldn't that be, especially since the latter was promised not the former?

And here I reach the last but not least of the promises: Bugfixes. Sadly, with some bugs in the game indeed having been fixed, much more new ones arose. 
[spoiler][strike]I've edited out the First bug as it was recently patched as far as I see![/strike][/spoiler]
Second one, equally infuriating - Troops AI and pathfinding is completely messed up. Very often your own troops pick very weird zig-zag-like patterns to reach a place, like a tower or something. It takes time + if youre the one sieging, you can't plan movement too well and risk getting your troops decimated.
On the defending side, large melee attacks aren't a problem to defend anymore, as they focus on your own melee troops instead of actually attacking and getting into your castle in the first place. As such, you can just micro-manage the enemy with your outside melee troops while your range units wipe them out.
The third one, the one that made me literally quit a map made by firefly themselves - units get stuck on enemy's spike traps. A problem that already was in the original (and I doubt it's a feature) that happened sporadically now happens almost every time.

Additional bugs I found throughout more gameplay that I find pretty annoying:
-Sometimes the game selects units you yourself did not. I don't know how that happens, but you can just casually micro-manage with your macemen, and then suddenly the game selects nearby archers for you. 
-Sometimes, the units you haven't selected are taking the same orders you give to the one you actually do have in selection.
-Woodcutters pick the nearest tree to their hut, but ignore whether that tree is quickly accessible or not. That means that if there's two trees, one a bit further from the woodcutter's hut but at his level so it's the quickest to get, but the second is the nearest from the hut despite being on a hill that requires a long walk to get into, the woodcutter picks the latter.
-When you stumble upon "armory is full" message when buying weapons, then no matter if you build more armories, you can't buy this specific weapon anymore until armory's capacity will be lower than 50.

Those are probably just the tip of the Iceberg, but they're absolutely sure to mess up old scenarios/campaigns that were working perfectly in the original, and even will be a problem in new maps.

I've mentioned a zoom feature previously - You can now not only zoom out to see more of the map, but also zoom in to see the details of new graphics and focus on some things better - At first I thought "that is actually neat!" and then I realized another infuriating problem... Every map starts being fully zoomed in. Every. Single. Time, with no option in the menu to set up the normal view as default. If you're like me, and actually like seeing things in a new map you just started playing, you will be bound to ultimately use the zoom two times, because it almost always zooms out to the maximum while pressing it for the first time. Another nauseating feature.

But... It's not like this remaster is deprived of any good features, there is actually quite a plentiful of them!
Customizable Free Build games are super nice, you can now set up random events and invasions to surprise you without the need of ruining your immersion by having to manually do so with constant F1 clicking, that's pretty neat!
The UI, textures (when they work correctly), redone screens such as the victory/defeat ones are all really well made!
Additionally, there is a ton of new Editor features that can absolutely boost creativity and help with making a lot of new unique maps - something I was hoping for a real lot, and was not disappointed. Additionally you can share the maps into workshop, which is nice. Would love to have a feature one day that would let the player create their own campaign, with story screens, briefings and such, and let that be shared in workshop too.

So, it's not like Firefly didn't put any love into this remaster, because they did, and I feel there's a lot of it. As they themselves said plentiful of times - nowadays, they're a small team, and on top of that, it releases in meantime of making a completely new Stronghold entry. Stronghold DE was their side project, and it shows, it painfully, painfully shows.
Hence why, I feel Firefly had released this game way too quickly. When you're making something as a small team, and break that small team down even further in order to make a side project, you HAVE to give that project some time in the oven. Some more time to listen to fans, listen more carefully, and to most importantly develop a game that will not be a rushed cluster of fixed old bugs vs new bugs.

I really hope for Crusader remaster too, but If it'll happen, I would want Firefly to approach it more seriously and carefully. Perhaps Stronghold DE throughout patches and DLCs will really become "Definitive", for now it's not. And while a lot of the added features are nice and fun, I can't recommend it in current state for anyone but diehard fans that can bear through all the current pains of it.

I fucking LOVE this one. The old Stronghold was already one of the favourite games of my childhood and this DE version honors it incredibly well. I have yet to find any significant issue or difference from the old version; the only thing right now that feels a bit unfamiliar are the new animations (woodcutter, bakers, etc.), but I must say that they are very well done and look awesome, so this is just me being nostalgic. I appreciate having the option to switch between the old spire and the new one, new controls while keeping the option to go back to the old ones, beautiful graphics, very stable gameplay, original audio... The only thing that I wasn't sure about is the omission of the Wolf and the Pig campaigns, which are coming in January. I am honestly not sure whether those were present in the original game back then or if they were also added later, but I have to say this - I was shocked at how low the price is and I would be more than happy to pay 20 EUR for this game, so getting the two DLCs for 6 EUR with many other planned upgrades on the way... This is a no-brainer for me and so it should be for you if you liked the original Stronghold. Stronghold DE is the highlight of 2023 for me, as far as gaming goes. Now, I really hope they will give the same care and love to Stronghold: Crusader and I also hope that they don't take too long; but thankfully, I know exactly how to make that time go by very fast. Thank you for this awesome remake and also for the very welcomed Czech subtitles!

The low entry point of this Definitive Edition doesn't quite justify the low effort put into the "Remaster" part of what this Remaster was expected to be. This episode is the exact same 20-year-old Stronghold with a few more-than-welcome (but how could it have been otherwise?...) quality-of-life features and slightly updated graphics to suit modern monitors, with a few more Siege maps and a (short) secondary campaign.

Those who expected Firefly to seize this opportunity to redesign the game by adding a Skirmish Trail, co-op and economy tweaks based on the Stronghold Crusader experience will get none of that here, with the developers stating clearly this will never happen. Subsequently, there are only 2 stances left. If you're merely happy to delve back into your beloved "childhood RTS" with a tad more content, then definitely go for this Definitive Edition. If you expected a Stronghold 2.0, you should avoid it instead as you'll feel the devs are just trying to milk an old cow playing on players' nostalgia. Both points of view are equally valid in my opinion so your choice should solely boil down to your level of expectations and fandom.

Since Steam doesn't allow for a Neutral review, I'll personally lean slightly towards the Negative side as I expected more from this Remaster. But as stated previously, your mileage may vary greatly. To put things into perspective however, I still rank the original Stronghold Crusader as the best episode in the whole franchise, including this latest addition.

I don't like how firefly keep slapping RTS label on their titles, when they lack the fundamental features of an RTS game. (and no, i am not talking about skirmish being missing.) Where is the camera grip, the replay feature, the multiplayer balance?
Do not get me wrong, i like the core gameplay of Stronghold, even with its lacking RTS features. It's a nice castle sim with some RTS elements, the king of the hill is fun to play (largely thanks to the backstabbing opportunities it creates) and all.

I don't like how the glorifyingly advertised features are broken at launch, (looking at you, multiplayer) even though i expect it to be fixed in coming updates.
[b] I don't like how firefly spends INSANE amount of effort on marketing and creating hype on a series with an ESTABLISHED AND DEDICATED FANBASE, and talk about being low on resources for actual development efforts. [/b]
I don't like how they are about to put a price tag on content that can never hold a candle to the existing, free, and superior content already available online (looking at you, upcoming DLC campaigns). If you are going to put a price tag on anything, do Robert some justice and put the remastered soundtrack as DLC(assuming there is one, maybe my ears are defying me and not allowing me to notice the difference)
I don't like how established QOL gets destroyed in a new version of the game(button Z cannot be used for both zooming in and out anymore!, you cannot click on the message video skip it and restore the minimap anymore!, V button is gone, although thats a rather minor one)
I don't like how some of the newly implemented QOL is lacking in common sense (who the hell would want to point and click on a flag button for unit rally point and not use the inarguably better method of number hotkeys, which was the implementation for the followup title to the original stronghold)
UI being stuck on corner is annoying, it's like windows 11 forcing the centered taskbar items (which they later realised should have the option to put it back to corner again)

The visual upgrade overall nice, but even that has some drawbacks, be it in terms of reduced texture moddability, or reduced discernability of certain elements.
The added hotkey mapping, and "click to select" mode on building hotkeys (which became the default behavior on future titles) is good.
But the ACTUAL good thing that came out of the remaster is the newly added map editor features, because that will allow mapmakers to make more interesting maps. Basically more tools to play with = good. Nice job on that one, the sole programmer of SH:DE!

Stronghold: Definitive Edition is kind of a mystery to me. I understand why it exists (the developer needs money and had to crank out something cheap and relatively low-effort) but at the same time I really don't. There's already an HD re-release of the original Stronghold, and Definitive Edition really doesn't add much that the HD re-release didn't already have. 

The biggest question I have is why the developers didn't improve the camera at all. I understand that they wanted to keep it as close to the original as possible, but.. the HD port already exists. It's not like you need to go through some complicated DOSBOX setup or extensive patching to get it to work. The problem with the camera is that the entire game is isometric, and you can only view the game world from four camera angles. On top of that, the game doesn't allow you to move the camera even partially off the game's map, which means that each camera angle cuts off a corner of the map. Hope nothing important's going on there.

Along with the camera problems comes the fact that the game's main mechanic is kinda broken. Most of the campaign maps rely on the idea that you have a small force against a larger invading force and use walls and fortifications to make up for the difference. The problem is that building walls isn't great - walls can be built in eight directions (including diagonals) but all wall improvements (towers, gates) can only be built in four directions. This wouldn't be a problem if the game had, say, a hotkey that would make it so that walls snap to straight lines - only as far as I can tell, unless it's not listed in the game's key bindings, no such hotkey exists.

The game also makes it hard to tell whether a wall will be effective or not. On one map, I built what I thought was a complete wall only to find out that the wall had a hole in it that the camera would not allow me to see no matter what angle I set it to. It's also hard to tell if an enemy can traverse a given piece of terrain.

All of this pales in comparison to the game's unit AI being a buggy mess. Units in this game will try to hit enemies even if they have no chance at doing so, sometimes to absolutely laughable effect, things like the enemy AI's catapults aiming into cliffs because they can see your walls on the other side. Unfortunately, this is a two-way street in that your units will also try to hit anything they can see, even if they can't actually see or hit it. 

I'd say avoid this until the bugs get patched out. Buy the HD re-release (Stronghold HD) instead at a fraction of the price, or better yet buy Stronghold Crusader HD which people still play online.

Stronghold has since I was a child been one of my favorite games. I've never really been to interested in RTS games but this game has always had a place in my heart. I've been playing this remake now for quite awhile now and I can happily say It's a really good remake! There are some small things here and there that could be improved upon and I hope the devs keep on updating this game as it's a really good game that really deserves their attention. 

Some of the flaws that I've noticed is the following: 
- Zooming is a fixed zoom and not "free zoom" if that makes sense. I would love for it to be so that you can zoom as much as you want or as little. The default zoom is either too much or too little, would be great with a middle ground or "free zoom". 
- Dialog can at times be hard to hear. I know you can adjust the music / dialog volume but it feels a bit off at times. 
- Enemy troops can enter the castle in walls that doesn't make sense for them to be able to enter. There is a gap that you cannot see and this is usually is around hills and rocks. I've lost a few battles because they've been able to enter when I thought it was closed. 
- When you are fully zoomed out there is very much aliasing, maybe some AA would be beneficial to add? I've noticed that this also applies for stone walls. 

Other than what I've written above I'm really happy with this release. It's not only good but actually really cheap compared to other remasters I've seen. It's basically the same thing you get with the HQ editions but you also get improvement on features and updated graphics plus more campaing and an updated multiplayer! If you're a big stronghold fan then this is the remake you've waited for!

It's 2001, you come back from school. It's Friday, so you have a free evening. You launch Stronghold, the new game of the little-known company Firefly Studios. The game runs with 20 FPS at best on your Pentium II 233 Mhz. Sometimes it's 15 FPS or lower when there are more units on the screen. But it doesn't matter, the important thing is you can just run this great game on your computer. 

And now, 22 years later, the magic returns. For me, it's a perfect remaster. No big changes, some small QoL improvements, a new campaign, new maps, improved textures, flying cows in high resolution, improved map editor. And integration with Steam Workshop, which already become a source of nice new maps (anyone else remember this site for original games? https://stronghold.heavengames.com/) And more FPS this time. 

The finished remaster (looking at you Konami) with already announced updates for a reasonable price (looking at you Konami again). Totally worth buying. And already waiting for Stronghold Crusader Definitive Edition.

Stronghold Definitive Edition: 🏰 A Castle Worth Storming Your Wallet For! 💰

I recently embarked on a medieval journey that left me craving more chivalry, strategy, and just a touch of insanity. Yes, my fellow gamers, I'm talking about the Stronghold Definitive Edition. If you've ever wondered whether a castle siege simulator could be worth its weight in gold, let me tell you, it's time to grab your catapult and aim for the drawbridge! 🏹🏰

From the moment you load up Stronghold Definitive Edition, you're greeted by a jester-like advisor who appears to have had one too many goblets of mead. This character alone is worth the price of admission. His quirky humor and penchant for making questionable strategic decisions will have you giggling through the entire campaign. Who needs a sensible advisor when you can have a manic jester leading the charge? 🤪🃏

The game's graphics might not be cutting-edge, but they carry an undeniable medieval charm. You'll witness armies of tiny, pixelated peasants scurrying about, diligently working to build your dream castle. And by "dream castle," I mean a ramshackle collection of wooden huts, surrounded by a perilous moat filled with more crocodiles than the Florida Everglades. Trust me; it's your very own "Deathtrap Manor"! 🏡🐊

The soundtrack, if you can call it that, is a collection of merry minstrels playing catchy tunes on their lutes. It might drive you to madness in the best way possible as you try to fend off waves of marauding foes. Battle drums, siege engines, and the screams of your besieged citizens will keep you on your toes, or at least, on the edge of your rickety battlements. 🎶🥁

Speaking of battles, the AI in Stronghold Definitive Edition is something to behold. It's as if the opposing lords have undergone rigorous training at the School of Inexplicable Siege Tactics. They'll attack your heavily fortified walls with a handful of archers, then offer to surrender while your castle is still standing strong. It's an AI rebellion of epic proportions! 🤖🏹

Stronghold Definitive Edition boasts a multiplayer mode that will have you and your friends competing to see who can turn their castle into the most spectacular disaster zone. It's the ultimate test of your strategic prowess and your ability to withstand the relentless banter of your fellow players. 👫🎮

In conclusion, Stronghold Definitive Edition is the ultimate medieval madness package. From the deranged advisor to the perplexing AI, and the musical stylings of our minstrels, it's a game that's worth every gold coin in your digital purse. So, go forth, noble gamer, and conquer this castle simulator. Your jester awaits with open arms and a catapult loaded with laughter! 🃏🏰😂💰

Unfortunately, there are too many problems with this game.

1. The camera zoom levels. They give us 3 viewpoints of zoom level, the 1st one is too zoomed in, 2nd is too zoomed out I needed something in between for this to be playable.
Example of the 1st zoom point (1920x1080): https://i.ibb.co/XkSFZX8/1st.png

Example of something that would be in between: https://i.ibb.co/CP5FSGq/original.png

2. Multiplayer doesn't work

3. When I select soldiers and they say something, the background noises get silenced but sometimes there's a bug when the soldier's voice us is also silenced, I think this is unnecessary because it breaks the experience and is not implemented well.

4. The graphics. While they look pretty good there are problems. For example buildings are too contrasting, this breaks the experience because it's too cluttered. When the people and the buildings are at the same level of visibility I have a hard time managing everything. In previous version the buildings were much softer and were blending with the environment very well. Also it feels that the graphics were enhanced by randomly using AI.

5. UI, scrolling, controls just aren't snappy enough.

Those are the main issues that I found within first 2 hours of gameplay. The game isn't that bad but it definitely feels like just another half-assed Firefly project.

If you've followed FireFly up until the release of Stronghold DE, then you'd know that they had delivered on pretty much everything they've promised, and for a very reasonable price too.

I'm pretty sure that everything from the original title is here, with an extra bit of polish. Visually everything looks fantastic, all the UI and control improvements are very welcome and well executed. All the old and iconic soundbites are here, completely re-recorded too if I understood correctly, if so - the delivery of the voice lines is as good as it's ever been.

Some may be disappointed by the lack of a skirmish mode (I know I was when they announced that there wouldn't be one), but the original didn't have it either and apparently it would have required a lot of extra coding time that they'd rather put into the base game and the additional campaign. So not a huge loss.

I've encountered no bugs during my first session of play.

All in all, an actually good "Definitive Edition" title, that truly delivers on what it promised to do: polish and visual updates.

Very excited on the two future small DLCs that add a bit of extra content for ACTUALLY reasonable prices. Some [i]other[/i] strategy game developers would charge up to 30 moneys for what FireFly offers for 2.5 moneys from those upcoming updates.

For what is a relative pittance (15 bucks is very affordable) Stronghold DE brings Stronghold back to modern hardware, the graphics update makes the game look crisp without ruining the original aesthetic and does an excellent job to translate it into the modern era.
The game looks as it does in -my memories- and not the jagged pixillated reality that loading OG Stronghold would do.
The modern control scheme for someone who hasn't played a while is nice as well, and if you've played any sort of sim or rts, you'll probably find it easy to pick up and play with minimal translation error. 

Also, you can play Fullscreen, borderless windowed -and- windowed without hassle. A problem which plagued HD, meaning you can now have a second window open, which in a world where most PCs have a dual screen setup is much appreciated, also the 3k unit limit is awesome.

At this price point with these quality of life changes, I would already consider Stronghold DE well worth the money, but now with proper Workshop support, a functional multiplayer and entirely new campaigns. Not only do you get the joy that is the original Stronghold, you get fresh content to go with it as well.

After playing for 9 hours, I had no major issues, no crashes, not CTDs, it ran smoothly and I was just castle building like I did when I was a wee pup.

Here's to hoping that Stronghold DE will pay off enough to convince Firefly to give Crusader the same treatment. So the people with lapsing memories of what is in which game will be able to play skirmish.

I LOVE stronghold, I have logged loads of hours in the HD edition and hundreds of hours in my childhood and will always have fond memories, and think everyone should try it. Saying that I CANNOT recommend Stronghold Definitive Edition and that is really upsetting.

From the start the opening movie is now wide screen but stretched. In fact nearly all the movies and character portraits are stretched to the point they are badly disfigured and pixelated.

There is no skirmish/bot mode. The new "castle trail" campaign which looks like the campaigns in crusader, is more invasion/siege maps with a map style menu. In my opinion, the new main menu has lost a lot of the charm the original one had.

The newer visuals are nice, though all the effects from the buildings makes the screen too busy when you have a big city. The models of the soldiers look stiff and plastic, especially against solid backdrops like marsh. The zoom and updated controls are great though.

The weakest point of the original Stronghold was the troop tactics. No formation, grouping, bad pathfinding etc. Which was fine in 2001 but nothing has changed in over 20 years and there is a big push for the multiplayer which will make it struggle against other RTSs.

Old maps are still here which is great (though they are dated 2023 for some reason) but this includes the one titled "user created map" which looks odd. 

Maybe when the new campaigns come out this be worth the time, but (to me) it feels like Firefly hopped on the remaster bandwagon and tried to stick something together and the title Stronghold: Definitive Edition is just that, a title, and does not represent a defining quality of the game. I think it should be the "steam addition" more than anything. 

Stronghold HD is currently £3.49 on steam, unless you want to support Firefly Studios (which is great!) I would recommend starting there and maybe "upgrading" for the multiplayer when you have completed the campaign.  
 
P.S change the default look of the scribe on startup, no one likes the new one.

Stronghold came out at the tail end of the golden era of RTS, right before developers stopped caring about adding meaty well paced campaigns full of personality to their games and started just shitting out games trying to be the new hot e-sport, until MOBAs took their lunch money, and the rest is history. So yes, Stronghold has a great campaign worth revisiting. As a game, it's more like a laser guided missile. Build. Demolish. Build in order to demolish. Plop down some farms. Man your walls. Man your siege engines. Go nuts. It is very focused. Its biggest success is that it has incredible depth, while simultaneously being super easy to control. Also, your units actually go where you order them to go, another craft that apparently got lost to time by RTS developers in the last 20 years. The remaster gives it a very welcome facelift, while adding a new campaign that's kicking my ass, so that's great. It doesn't add skirmish and co-op, but personally I don't mind. That's not what Stronghold is. It's you and your walls against carefully scripted and balanced challenges, at least for me. It's being offered at a reasonable price, and most importantly, it has aged well and is still worth playing today.

Stronghold Definitive Edition is a nostalgic trip back to the classic castle-building real-time strategy (RTS) game from 2001, and it's a delightful experience for both returning fans and newcomers. The game retains the essence of the original while offering significant improvements in graphics and controls.

One of the standout features of Stronghold Definitive Edition is its attention to detail in recreating the medieval atmosphere. The improved graphics breathe new life into the game, with intricately designed buildings, lush landscapes, and charming character animations. The visual overhaul makes it clear that the developers put a lot of effort into modernizing this classic title.

This is simply a case of 'typical Firefly Studios', sadly. The usual - no imagination, no upgrades other than some terribly performed and generic story lines and with a 'do as little as possible for a maximum amount of money' attitude, this really is everything I expected it to be - a disappointment.  

These days, there are literal one-man developers whom make incredible games and Firefly Studios seems to be forever behind the times and lazy. Take a look at the comments section on any of their social media - they completely ignore the criticism's and focus entirely on the fans with the lowest IQ. They pump out these horrific games and 'upgrades' but the reality is that this is hardly any different from the original Stronghold. Why not add being able to put your troops into formations? This game has the same aura as COD games - rinse and repeat the same maps, the same engines, the same everything other than a quick polish. Pathetic.

These guys really do need to start again at foundation level and either hire a new and fresh team with talent (instead of the decrepit and ancient team that has clung on for 20 years - see their YT channel) or move on to making appalling Apps because this game does not currently fit in with the 'gaming' market.

This is a very nicely produced remaster of the original game. It sticks with the original features although it does add some extra maps and challenges and a multiplayer server. The visuals and the audio have been redone with original artists and voice actors giving their talents to help this improvement in quality. It looks really good on a modern screen with the animations and static images looking both faithful to the original style but also very smooth for modern 2D look. 

The game also allows you an easy access to a modern layout for controls and moving the screen about (WSAD) or the classic at the start, as well as redefining keys. Nice touches that show they've put some thought into this.

You know that feeling you get when you remember an old game you used to nolife when you were a kid, and come back to it only to find it hasn't aged well? Well, this game's kind of the opposite. It feels like coming back to an old game, and it's exactly the way your nostalgia brain remembers it. Least that's how it was for me.

I was really looking forward to this, but if you have any other version of the original Stronghold, I'm not sure it's worth paying the money for it. Things like being able to play in borderless are great, and some of the graphic upgrades look nice, but what Stronghold really needed was more QoL, improved unit/building AI and hotkeys. Even in some of the changes that they've made there's glaring issues with the design. Stronghold was a great RTS when it released in 2001, but the very basic control and AI were ultimately shit at the time and they're still shit now.

Perhaps after some time it'll be worth picking up, but as it stands now, I'd avoid it entirely.

It's not groundbreaking and I really wish they'd have included SP skirmish in this one, but for that price I can't really complain as what's there is solid: a new campaign, revamped visuals and beautiful animations.

I am not happy to write this review, since it is the first time I give a thumbs down for a Firefly title (Well, SH3 was bad, but this is quite obvious!). 
After playing both demos and looking through the missions of the final release, I am not satisfied with SH:DE. The game requires much more polishing regarding mission design, story telling with regard to the new campaign as well as bug fixing. 
To provide some examples: There are UI elements that are disproportionate, some textures lack details compared to the original release (e.g. wooden walls), the scribe seems to be less vivid when it comes to commenting on events throughout the campaign... and crashes are also a thing! Several bugs that existed for 20+ years now have not been fixed yet. 
But most importantly, I am not sure, if the level design is intended the way it is. Mission 1 plays a bit like mission 13 of the original: Move your crossbowmen, so they can shoot the enemy, wait for enemy units to be killed, repeat... I hope that Firefly is going to improve SH:DE with patches to come. I continue to be faithful, since SH1 is a great game in its core, which is why I recommend to wait with the purchase.

I've been a fan of Stronghold since I was 7 years old. I still remember opening the original CD disk and now, at 29, I'm reliving those moments with the Stronghold Definitive Edition on Steam.

This remaster is like stepping into a time machine. The graphics are sharper and the gameplay smoother, but the heart of Stronghold, the thrill of building your castle and fending off enemies hasn't changed a bit. It’s awesome to see how the game that I’ve kept on my shelf for years, still holds up today, just with a fresh coat of paint.

For anyone who loved the original or is just curious about a classic, this game is a must-try. It's simple: if you want to experience a piece of strategy game history with a modern touch, this game is the way to go. It's not just a game to me, it's a piece of my childhood, and I'm stoked to see it come back to life. <3
